content.description:
In a laboratory population of fruit flies, body color is determined by a single gene with a wild-type allele associated with black body color and a mutant allele associated with yellow body color. A group of researchers hypothesizes that the mutation in fruit flies that causes the yellow body is sex-linked. They also hypothesize that this mutation results in a change in the structure of the sex combs, bristle-like structures on the front legs of male flies that facilitate mating.

To determine the inheritance pattern of the mutant allele, researchers crossed yellow-bodied females with wild-type males. Flies from the <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> generation were then crossed. content.question: Based on the data in Table 1, which of the following is the most likely inheritance pattern for the mutant allele?

choices.label: The mutant allele is <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>-linked dominant.
The mutant allele is <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>-linked recessive.
The mutant allele is autosomal (non-sex-linked) recessive.
The mutant allele is <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>-linked.

content.answer: The mutant allele is <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>-linked recessive.
